cards.front: What is the difference between accuracy and precision?
cards.back:
Accuracy: How close to the TRUE value
Precision: How close measurements are to EACH OTHER

You can be precise but inaccurate (tight cluster far from target), or accurate but imprecise (scattered around target).

cards.front: What is the formula for standard error of the mean?
cards.back:
σ_mean = s / √n

Where:
• s = sample standard deviation
• n = number of measurements

More measurements reduce uncertainty, but with √n diminishing returns.

cards.front: How do you interpret DMM accuracy ±(0.5% + 2 digits)?
cards.back:
Total uncertainty = (0.5% of reading) + (2 × last digit value)

Example: Reading 1.234V on a 3-digit display
• 0.5% of 1.234 = 0.00617V
• 2 digits = 0.002V
• Total: ±0.008V

Result: 1.234V ± 0.008V

cards.front: What is the error propagation formula for multiplication and division?
cards.back:
For z = xy or z = x/y:

δz = √(δx² + δy²)

Use RELATIVE uncertainties (δ = Δ/value), not absolute.
Add relative uncertainties in quadrature (root-sum-square).

cards.front: What is the error propagation formula for addition and subtraction?
cards.back:
For z = x ± y:

Δz = √(Δx² + Δy²)

Use ABSOLUTE uncertainties (Δ), not relative.
Absolute uncertainties add in quadrature.

cards.front: What is 'loading error' and how can you minimize it?
cards.back:
Loading error: Measurement instrument affects the circuit being measured.

Minimize by:
• Voltmeter: Use high input impedance (10MΩ+)
• Ammeter: Use low internal resistance
• Oscilloscope: Use 10× probe for less loading
• Resistance: Disconnect component from circuit

cards.front: How do you read Vpp and frequency from an oscilloscope?
cards.back:
Vpp = (peak-to-peak vertical divisions) × (V/div setting)

Period T = (divisions for one cycle) × (time/div setting)

Frequency f = 1/T

Always check probe attenuation (1× vs 10×)!

cards.front: Why can't you measure resistance with a component powered in-circuit?
cards.back:
Three problems:

1. Circuit voltage overwhelms DMM's measurement voltage
2. Parallel paths change apparent resistance
3. Risk of damaging DMM or circuit

Always: Power off, disconnect one lead, then measure.

cards.front: For z = xⁿ, what is the relative uncertainty δz?
cards.back:
δz = |n| × δx

The exponent MULTIPLIES the relative uncertainty.

Examples:
• z = x² → δz = 2δx
• z = √x = x^0.5 → δz = 0.5δx
• z = 1/x = x⁻¹ → δz = δx

cards.front: What is the difference between systematic and random errors?
cards.back:
Systematic: Consistent bias in one direction
• Examples: Calibration offset, parallax, temperature drift
• Fix: Calibrate, correct, eliminate cause

Random: Unpredictable scatter around true value
• Examples: Electrical noise, reading variation, vibration
• Fix: Average multiple measurements
